feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.summary: Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Montgomery

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 25 at 2:30PM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ
entry.summary:
At 230 PM MST, Doppler radar was tracking a cluster of strong thunderstorms along a line extending from 9 miles northeast of Globe to Central Heights-Midland City to near Miami. Movement was east at 10 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph and half inch hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor damage to outdoor objects is possible.
Locations impacted include... Globe, San Carlos, Miami, Top Of The World, Central Heights-Midland City, Cutter, Top-Of-The-World, Claypool, and Inspiration.
This includes the following highways... US Highway 60 between mile markers 232 and 271. AZ Route 70 between mile markers 253 and 271. AZ Route 77 between mile markers 156 and 170.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Pinal/Superstition Mountains; San Carlos; Dripping Springs; Globe/Miami; Southeast Gila County

cap:parameter.value: STRONG THUNDERSTORMS WILL IMPACT GILA AND PINAL COUNTIES THROUGH 330 PM MST

entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued September 25 at 2:28PM MST until September 25 at 3:15PM MST by NWS Tucson AZ
entry.summary:
SVRTWC
The National Weather Service in Tucson has issued a
* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for... South Central Cochise County in southeastern Arizona...
* Until 315 PM MST.
* At 228 PM MST, a severe thunderstorm was located near Bisbee-Douglas Airport, moving southeast at 15 mph.
HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage to roofs, siding, and trees.
* Locations impacted include... Douglas, Bisbee-Douglas Airport and Pirtleville.
This includes the following highways... Route 80 between mile markers 349 and 375. Route 191 between mile markers 1 and 15.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cochise, AZ

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued September 25 at 2:24PM MST until September 25 at 5:30PM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ
entry.summary:
FFWPSR
The National Weather Service in Phoenix has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Gila County in east central Arizona... Maricopa County in south central Arizona... Pinal County in southeastern Arizona...
* Until 530 PM MST.
* At 224 PM MST, the public reported thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 0.5 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is already occurring.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding.
SOURCE...Public reported.
IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Globe, Miami, Claypool, Central Heights-Midland City, Top-Of-The-World and Inspiration.
This includes the following highways... AZ Route 188 between mile markers 214 and 224. US Highway 60 between mile markers 237 and 245. AZ Route 70 between mile markers 253 and 254.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Gila, AZ; Maricopa, AZ; Pinal, AZ

cap:parameter.value: NWS: FLASH FLOOD WARNING this area til 5:30 PM MST. Avoid flooded areas.

National Weather Service: A FLASH FLOOD WARNING is in effect for this area until 5:30 PM MST. This is a dangerous and life-threatening situation. Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 25 at 2:22PM MST by NWS Flagstaff AZ
entry.summary:
At 222 PM MST /322 PM MDT/, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 9 miles south of Bill Williams Mountain, or 25 miles northeast of Chino Valley, moving northeast at 20 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph and half inch size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor damage to outdoor objects is possible.
Locations impacted include... Williams, Bill Williams Mountain, Kaibab Lake, Sherwood Forest Estates, Sycamore Falls, Scholz Lake, Whitehorse Lake, Red Lake, J.D. Dam Lake, Garland Prairie, Parks, H A Clark Memorial Field and Sycamore Canyon Wilderness.
This includes the following highways... Interstate 40 between mile markers 153 and 173. Business Interstate 40 between mile markers 163 and 165. State Route 89 between mile markers 355 and 356. State Route 64 between mile markers 186 and 194.
This includes the following recreation areas and campgrounds... White Horse Lake Campground, Camp Raymond, Dogtown Lake Campground, Kaibab Lake Campground and Bill Williams Campground.
This includes the following swimming holes... Sycamore Falls, Lower Sycamore Falls "The Golden Pond" and Paradise Forks.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coconino Plateau; Yavapai County Mountains; Western Mogollon Rim; Yavapai County Valleys and Basins; Oak Creek and Sycamore Canyons

entry.summary:

* WHERE...A portion of central California, including the following county, Madera.
* WHEN...Until 530 PM PDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 219 PM PDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. entry.title: Flood Advisory issued September 25 at 5:14PM EDT until September 25 at 8:15PM EDT by NWS Albany NY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of east central New York, including the following counties, Albany, Rensselaer, Saratoga, Schenectady and Washington.
* WHEN...Until 815 PM EDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas as well as along small rivers/tributaries. Overflowing poor drainage areas. Ponding of water in urban or other areas is occurring or is imminent.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 512 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rainfall with high rainfall rates up to 1 inch per hour. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Albany, Schenectady, Troy, Clifton Park, Rotterdam, Saratoga Springs, East Greenbush, Cohoes, Watervliet, Rensselaer, Colonie, Scotia, Mechanicville, Latham, Delmar, Guilderland, Niskayuna, Milton, Ballston Spa and Menands. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Albany, NY; Rensselaer, NY; Saratoga, NY; Schenectady, NY; Washington, NY

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 815 PM EDT THIS EVENING

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued September 25 at 4:47PM EDT until September 26 at 12:00AM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Up to one half foot of inundation above ground level expected in low lying areas due to tidal flooding.
* WHERE...Shoreline in Anne Arundel County.
* WHEN...Until midnight EDT tonight, especially around the time of high tide.
* IMPACTS...At 2.6 feet, water may begin to pond in the parking lot at Annapolis City Dock, and surround the Alex Haley Memorial.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Tides one to one and a half feet above normal. The next high tide at Annapolis U.S. Naval Academy is at 8:46 PM.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Anne Arundel

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL MIDNIGHT EDT TONIGHT

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued September 25 at 3:06PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
entry.summary:
AQAHGX
The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has issued an Ozone Action Day for the Houston, Galveston, and Brazoria area for Friday, September 26, 2025.
Atmospheric conditions are expected to be favorable for producing high levels of ozone pollution in the Houston, Galveston, and surrounding areas on Friday. You can help prevent ozone pollution by sharing a ride, walking, riding a bicycle, taking your lunch to work, avoiding drive through lanes, conserving energy and keeping your vehicle properly tuned.
For more information on ozone: Ozone: The Facts www.tceq.texas.gov/airquality/monops/ozonefacts.html EPA AirNow: www.airnow.gov/?city=Houston&state=TX&country=USA Take Care of Texas: www.takecareoftexas.org/conservation-tips/keep-our-air-clean
entry.cap:areaDesc: Inland Harris; Inland Brazoria; Inland Galveston; Coastal Harris; Coastal Brazoria; Coastal Galveston; Brazoria Islands; Galveston Island; Bolivar Peninsula

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued September 25 at 3:03PM CDT by NWS Fort Worth TX
entry.summary:
AQAFWD
The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has issued an Ozone Action Day for the Dallas-Fort Worth area for Friday, September 26, 2025.
Atmospheric conditions are expected to be favorable for producing high levels of ozone air pollution in the Dallas-Fort Worth area on Friday. You can help prevent ozone pollution by sharing a ride, walking, riding a bicycle, taking your lunch to work, avoiding drive-through lanes, conserving energy, and keeping your vehicle properly tuned.
For more information on ozone:
Ozone: The Facts (www.tceq.texas.gov/goto/ozonefacts)
Air North Texas: (www.airnorthtexas.org)
EPA Air Now (www.airnow.gov/index.cfm?action.local_state&STATEID=45&TAB=0)
Take care of Texas (www.takecareoftexas.org)
North Central Texas Council of Governments Air Quality (www.nctcog.org/trans/air/index.asp)
entry.cap:areaDesc: Wise; Denton; Collin; Hunt; Parker; Tarrant; Dallas; Rockwall; Kaufman; Hood; Johnson; Ellis; Henderson

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued September 25 at 1:00PM MST until September 25 at 3:30PM MST by NWS Tucson AZ
entry.summary:
FFWTWC
The National Weather Service in Tucson has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... West Central Cochise County in southeastern Arizona...
* Until 330 PM MST.
* At 100 PM MST, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Up to 1 inch of rain has fallen. Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding.
SOURCE...Radar and automated gauges. Kartchner Caverns gauge recorded 1.06 inches in 30 minutes.
IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Kartchner Caverns State Park.
This includes Route 90 between mile markers 294 and 301.
This includes the following streams and drainages... Apache Canyon, Cadillac Wash, Middle Canyon Wash, San Pedro River, Cienega Creek, Mescal Arroyo and Montosa Canyon.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cochise, AZ

cap:parameter.value: NWS: FLASH FLOOD WARNING this area til 3:30 PM MST. Avoid flooded areas.

National Weather Service: A FLASH FLOOD WARNING is in effect for this area until 3:30 PM MST. This is a dangerous and life-threatening situation. Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued September 25 at 12:32PM PDT by NWS Spokane WA
entry.summary:
An Air Quality Alert has been issued by the following agencies:
Washington Department of Ecology
An Air Quality Alert has been issued for Chelan, Douglas and Okanogan County until further notice, due to current and expected wildfire smoke from regional fires. Particulate matter (PM2.5) levels are expected to be unhealthy in many areas. When air quality is unhealthy, everyone should reduce exposure. Limit time outside, avoid strenuous outdoor activity, and follow tips for cleaner indoor air.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Chelan, WA; Douglas, WA; Okanogan, WA

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued September 26 at 3:53AM ChST until September 29 at 6:00AM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 8 to 11 feet and dangerous rip currents.
* WHERE...North facing reefs of the Marianas.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM ChST Monday.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Long-period northerly swell emanating from Tropical Storm Neoguri is producing 8 to 10 foot surf along north facing reefs of the Marianas. An increase in swell magnitude and period may allow surf to build an additional foot or two over the weekend.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Guam; Rota; Tinian; Saipan

cap:parameter.value: HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 AM CHST MONDAY... ...HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH LATE SUNDAY NIGHT

entry.title: High Wind Warning issued September 25 at 9:47AM AKDT until September 26 at 10:00PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...South winds around 40 mph with gusts up to 70 mph expected.
* WHERE...Petersburg Borough, Western Kupreanof Island and Kuiu Island and City and Borough of Wrangell.
* WHEN...From 10 AM to 10 PM AKDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...High winds will blow around unsecured object. The strong winds may blow down trees, damage property and cause power outages. Travel will be difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Highest wind speeds are expected to be associated with a wind shift from the east to the south. At this time, expecting this wind shift to occur in the early afternoon Friday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Petersburg Borough; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island; City and Borough of Wrangell

cap:parameter.value: HIGH WIND WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 10 AM TO 10 PM AKDT FRIDAY

entry.title: High Wind Warning issued September 25 at 9:47AM AKDT until September 26 at 7:00PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Southeast winds 35 to 45 mph with wind gusts ranging from 60 to 70 mph expected. Winds are expected to shift to the south late morning to early afternoon.
* WHERE...Ketchikan Gateway Borough and Annette Island.
* WHEN...From 7 AM to 7 PM AKDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...High winds will blow around unsecured objects, blow down trees and damage property. Power outages are possible. Travel will be difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Wind gusts have a chance to exceed 80 mph near upper elevation sites on Annette Island, such as Yellow Hill. As winds shift to the south, areas on the South Tongass Highway around Mountain Point and areas past Point Higgins on North Tongass Highway have the highest likelihood for strong gusts.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Annette Island

cap:parameter.value: HIGH WIND WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 7 AM TO 7 PM AKDT FRIDAY

entry.title: High Wind Warning issued September 25 at 9:47AM AKDT until September 26 at 7:00PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...East winds around 35 mph with gusts up to 60 mph expected.
* WHERE...City and Borough of Sitka.
* WHEN...From 10 AM to 7 PM AKDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...High winds will blow around unsecured objects. The strong winds may blow down trees, damage property and cause power outages. Travel will be difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Sitka has the highest uncertainty for high winds. Small changes to the storm track will have major implications regarding both the direction and magnitude of wind gusts. Stay tuned for updates.
entry.cap:areaDesc: City and Borough of Sitka

cap:parameter.value: HIGH WIND WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 10 AM TO 7 PM AKDT FRIDAY

entry.title: High Wind Warning issued September 25 at 9:47AM AKDT until September 26 at 7:00PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...South to southwest winds around 45 mph with gusts up to 80 mph expected.
* WHERE...Prince of Wales Island.
* WHEN...From 7 AM to 7 PM AKDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...High winds will blow around unsecured objects, may damage property, blow down trees, and cause power outages.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Strongest wind gusts are expected on the northern end of Prince of Wales Island. Winds are expected to rapidly shift to the southwest late Friday morning to early afternoon, followed by strongest gusts. Towards Craig and Klawock, expecting gusts up to 65 mph associated with the wind shift.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Prince of Wales Island

entry.title: Flood Watch issued September 25 at 7:30AM HST until September 26 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
..FLOOD WATCH FOR KAUAI AND NIIHAU...
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.
* WHERE...Niihau and Kauai.
* WHEN...Through Friday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Flood prone roads and other low lying areas may be closed due to elevated runoff and overflowing streams. Urban areas may receive more significant flooding and property damage due to rapid runoff.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - A front will stall near Kauai today and bring widespread showers. An approaching upper low will destabilize the atmosphere across this area and bring the potential for shower enhancement along with isolated thunderstorms that will continue through the day Friday. Heavy rain lingering over the same areas on Kauai and Niihau may result in flash flooding.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Niihau; Kauai Southwest; Kauai Mountains; Kauai North; Kauai East; Kauai South

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued September 25 at 7:18AM PDT until September 25 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS Pendleton OR
entry.summary:
...DRY AND WINDY CONDITIONS EXPECTED THROUGH THE CASCADE GAPS ON THIS AFTERNOON AND TONIGHT...
.A dry cold front combined with recent warming temperatures will create dry and windy conditions, especially through the Cascade Gaps, Kittitas Valley, and the east slopes south into Oregon. Dry and windy conditions will increase the risk of wildfire spread today and tonight.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zones 690 Kittitas Valley and 695 East Washington South Central Cascade Mountains.
* TIMING...From 11 AM this morning to 11 PM PDT this evening.
* WINDS...Northwest 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 45 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 20 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fire that develops will catch and spread quickly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kittitas Valley; East Washington South Central Cascade Mountains

entry.title: Flood Warning issued September 25 at 9:14AM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Astor affecting Volusia and Lake Counties.
.The river is forecast to gradually decline, remaining in Minor Flood stage into the weekend.
For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Minor flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued this evening at 1100 PM EDT.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 2.3 feet, Many docks become submerged along the river and in canals in the Astor community. Water enters yards of properties on Bartram Road, Holiday Circle and along Wild Hog Road on the Lake County side. In Volusia County, water encroaches yards of homes on the river side of Alice Drive. No wake zones are in effect from near the South Moon Canal to approximately 800 feet south of the Riverview lodge.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 2.4 feet. - Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:30 AM EDT Thursday was 2.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is forecast to continue a slow decline late this week while remaining in minor flood. - Flood stage is 2.3 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued September 25 at 2:06AM PDT until September 26 at 9:00AM PDT by NWS Spokane WA
entry.summary:
...VIGOROUS DRY COLD FRONT PASSAGE ON THURSDAY...
.A dry cold front will sweep across the Inland Northwest Thursday afternoon and evening. Winds will increase through the day with gusty westerly winds by the afternoon. Winds will see a shift from west-southwest to west-northwest across north central Washington late afternoon to early evening. Winds will remain gusty along the east slopes of the central Cascade Mountains through Thursday night with dry air mixing down and fair to poor relative humidity recovery on mid slopes and ridge tops.
* Affected Area: East Washington Central Cascades (Zone 696).
* Winds: West-Northwest 10 to 15 mph with gusts up to 30 mph in the valleys and 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 40 mph in the mountains.
* Relative Humidities: 11 to 26 percent in the valleys and 20 to 33 percent over the higher terrain.
* Impacts: Rapid fire spread for any new or ongoing fires.
entry.cap:areaDesc: East Washington Central Cascades

cap:parameter.value: RED FLAG WARNING NOW IN EFFECT FROM 11 AM THIS MORNING TO 9 AM PDT FRIDAY FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONE 696

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued September 25 at 2:06AM PDT until September 25 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS Spokane WA
entry.summary:
...VIGOROUS DRY COLD FRONT PASSAGE ON THURSDAY...
.A dry cold front will sweep across the Inland Northwest Thursday afternoon and evening. Winds will increase through the day with gusty westerly winds by the afternoon. Winds will see a shift from west-southwest to west-northwest across north central Washington late afternoon to early evening. Winds will remain gusty along the east slopes of the central Cascade Mountains through Thursday night with dry air mixing down and fair to poor relative humidity recovery on mid slopes and ridge tops.
* Affected Area: East Portion of North Cascades National Park/Lake Chelan National Recreation Area (Zone 697), East Washington North Cascades (Zone 698), Colville Reservation (Zone 702), Okanogan Valley (Zone 703), Methow Valley (Zone 704), Foothills of Central Washington Cascades (Zone 705), Waterville Plateau (Zone 706), Western Columbia Basin (Zone 707), Eastern Columbia Basin -Palouse -Spokane Area (Zone 708) and Lower Palouse -Snake River (Zone 709).
* Winds: West 15 to 20 mph with gusts up to 35 mph. Exposed ridges along the east slopes of the Cascades to the Waterville Plateau will see west winds 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 35 to 40 mph.
* Relative Humidities: 8 to 18 percent at lower elevations below 3000 feet and 15 to 25 percent in the higher terrain above 3000 feet.
* Impacts: Rapid fire spread for any new or ongoing fires.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 25 at 5:19PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
Tropical Storm Bauloi (26W), now located near 11.4N 128.6E, has exited the region and and continues to move west-northwest across the Philippine Sea. A wet monsoon-like pattern continues for Yap and Palau in its wake, but seas and surf are diminishing. Altimetry data indicates that seas have diminished to 6 to 8 feet near Palau, and the Small Craft Advisory was allowed to expire for Palau waters late this morning. West to northwest swell is diminishing as well, and surf is expected to fall below hazardous levels along north and west facing reefs of Palau, and west facing reefs of Yap late overnight.
This will be the last Special Weather Statement issued for Tropical Storm Bualoi. Residents and mariners should continue to monitor local sea and surf conditions and forecasts, and to practice caution when near or on the water. Stay up to date with the latest forecasts for the region at weather.gov/gum/PublicForecasts and any information shared by WSO Palau and WSO Yap for their local regions, as well as JTWC bulletins under WTPN31 PGTW.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Yap; Melekeok; Airai; Koror; Peleliu; Angaur

cap:parameter.value: TROPICAL STORM BUALOI (26W) HAS EXITED THE REGION... ...ELEVATED SWELL AND SURF DIMINISHING OVERNIGHT

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued September 23 at 10:06AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
ESFSJU
A strong tropical wave, designated as Invest 94L by the National Hurricane Center, will approach the local islands as early as Tuesday night, enhancing the chances of flooding through at least late Thursday.
The first round of showers will reach the Virgin Islands on Tuesday night and early Wednesday, with periods of moderate to heavy rain anticipated. The rain will then spread across Vieques, Culebra, and east and southeast Puerto Rico. This unsettled weather pattern is expected to linger into at least Thursday. So far, the heaviest activity should be focused along the vicinity of the Virgin Islands and the eastern third of Puerto Rico.
The tropical wave appears to have a good structure in the low and mid levels, and a big area of above than normal moisture content. Also, previous rainfalls maintain soils saturated along portions of the interior, western and the extreme east of Puerto Rico. Soils are also saturated in portions of St.Croix and St. Thomas, according to the National Moisture Soil Analysis. However, soils are not saturated along the east-interior, and most of southern Puerto Rico. U.S.Geological Survey sensors shows that most streams are running near normal, but some rivers are running below normal in the east-interior and southeast.
Although it is not expected to be raining all day long, or everywhere at the same time, this wet period will increase the likelihood of experiencing urban and small stream flooding, landslides, rapid river rises, and isolated flash flood and rivers reaching flood stage. It is worth mentioning, that even though rivers are not as high in the east, these rivers tend to react quickly. Across the Virgin Islands, water surges along drainage guts are a concern as well.
The local guidance are in agreement that the territories will observe these rains, but there is some uncertainty in the exact amounts, timing and location. For now, the official forecast calls for 2 to 4 inches and isolated amounts up to 6 inches through the entire period (late Tuesday through late Thursday).
Residents and visitors are urged to stay away from rivers and flood prone areas, and to stay tuned to any changes in the forecast and flood products issued by the Weather Forecast Office.
